definition:
Let $\{ X_i : i \in I \}$ be a collection of modules in some category of
modules. Then the [*direct sum*]{} $\coprod_{i \in I} X_i$ of that
collection is the submodule of the of the $X_i$ consisting of all
elements $(x_i)$ such that all but a finite number of the $x_i$ are
zero.

For each $j \in I$ we have a [*projection*]{}
$p_j : \coprod_{i \in I} X_i \to X_j$ defined by $(x_i) \mapsto x_j$,
and an [*injection*]{} $\lambda_j : X_j \to \coprod_{i \in I} X_i$ where
an element $x_j$ of $X_j$ maps to the element of $\coprod_{i \in I} X_i$
whose $j$th term is $x_j$ and every other term is zero.

The direct sum $\coprod_{i \in I} X_i$ satisfies a certain universal
property. Namely, if $Y$ is a module and there exist homomorphisms
$f_i : Y \to X_i$ for all $i \in I$, then there exists a unique
homomorphism $\phi : \coprod_{i \in I} X_i \to Y$ satisfying
$p_i \phi = f_i$ for all $i \in I$. $$\xymatrix{
  X_i
  &
  &
  Y
        \ar[ll]_{f_i}
  \\
  &
  \coprod_{i \in I} X_i
        \ar[ul]^{p_i}
        \ar@{-->}[ur]_{\phi}
}$$

The direct sum is often referred to as the [*weak direct sum*]{} or
simply the [*sum*]{}.

Compare this to the direct product of modules.

Often an internal direct sum is written as $\bigoplus_{i \in I} X_i$.
